awd_titl_txt: I-Corps: Non-invasive ultrasound technology for tactile stimulation to create a sense of touch
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the development of small, wearable devices that deliver virtual tactile perception to non-invasively stimulate sensory nerves creating a sense of touch to the user. This will enable new immersive virtual experiences for remote K-12 learning, therapeutic healthcare for patients with cognitive and motor function needs, and precise tactile feedback during recreational gaming as well as training for competitive athletes.  Near-term commercial applications appear focus on healthcare to provide increased sensitivity in rehabilitation for patients such as those with spinal cord injuries (SCI) that currently rely on large sensorimotor haptic feedback devices that use simple motors to briefly restore the sense of touch. This device is designed as a wristband that emits ultrasonic waves that may more precisely target nerve clusters in the brain and spinal cord to produce a more sensitive response. The technology may be expanded to other neurotechnology applications in healthcare, education, and entertainment. 

This I-Corps project is based on the development of a wristband that emits ultrasonic waves that may precisely and noninvasively target nerve clusters in the brain and spinal cord as well as other areas. Traditional neuromodulation is done using electrical current, but recent research has demonstrated that focal ultrasound stimulation has several advantages over electrical stimulation, including deeper penetration into tissue and increased spatio-temporal specificity. The proposed technology may be used to noninvasively target nerves that would require invasive procedures for the electrical field to reach (e.g., deep brain stimulation). Focal ultrasound stimulation previously has been used for neuromodulation in the central nervous system (e.g., activation of neural circuits) and in the peripheral nervous system (activation of cholinergic nerves in the spleen and bladder muscle control). The core of this innovation is based on research to determine exactly how to spatiotemporally stimulate neural cells. The proposed device will combine serial imaging using ultrasound with novel deep learning algorithms trained to segment different body segments including nerves and neural computational models that encode learned stimulation spatiotemporal parameters of the focal ultrasound pulse for naturalistic neuromodulation.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
This NSF I-Corps award provided the framework and training to understand the potential applications, customers and key value propositions of a new technology arising from university research into focused ultrasound stimulation with better solutions for neuromodulation. The sense of touch is one of the first senses to develop in babies, has been shown to be crucially involved in how children acquire structured knowledge about the world during development, and is known to heighten sensory experiences and memory formation. While AR and VR technologies have been making huge strides towards providing a seamless visual and auditory experience virtually, there has been little to no progress on virtual tactile technologies. We envision using ultrasound technology to non-invasively stimulate sensory nerves in a safe and precise way in the forearm, creating a sense of touch to the user. The wearable sensor will be able to calibrate the duration and location of each stimulus using a deep neural network that has learned a mapping between different sensory signals and the patterns of nerve activation needed to elicit them.

During the award, the team explored potential applications and customer segments in video game human computer interfaces, museum accessibility for neurodivergent guests, as well as healthcare providers and researchers in the fields of traumatic brain/nerve injury, neuropathic pain, and other peripheral nervous system pathologies.  The team conducted over 150 customer discovery interviews and collected evidence. Pivots were made away from the museum accessibility market and video game industry, toward healthcare. We also pivoted away from ultrasound imaging of nerve injury and toward using focused ultrasound for treatment of pain.  Key Value Propositions developed were to reduce the number of painful procedures for neuropathic patients, increase conclusive diagnosis from ultrasound imaging for neurosurgeons, and improve the quality of care for at-home treatments of nerve injuries.

This led to the formation of a startup, UltraNeuro, Inc., to commercialize this technology.  After I-Corps the team worked on further customer discovery activity to hone product-market fit.  The team participated in a number of accelerator and entrepreneurial Fellowship programs to develop a viable business model and plan. The team did raise pre-seed funding from a VC with the intent raise further funding.  Unfortunately, at this time, the team has been unable to secure additional funding to further develop the product or the company.  The team has taken positions in industry where they are applying the techniques learned in I-Corps training. The project provided the team with immersive training and hands-on experience to investigate the application of an emerging new technology from a university lab. The team found that the customer discovery and validation framework is an invaluable process. Through this work the team became comfortable in communicating with staff and decision makers in industry. The new skills and understanding developed during this I-Corps project resulted in significant professional development.

 


Last Modified: 04/27/2023
Modified by: Roman Lubynsky
